subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: keyboard map uploaded
msgSnippet: ... I am not sure how useful having the most used letters at the front of the alphabet would be.  On the other hand, for those who are not linguists, i.e. most
messageBody:
oliver langan wrote:

> As for using sound frequency as the official order of the alphabet, I
> suspect that this will remove the convenient pairing of voiced and
> unvoiced characters as in Read's manual.

I am not sure how useful having the most used letters at the front of
the alphabet would be. On the other hand, for those who are not
linguists, i.e. most of us, is it important that voiced and unvoiced
pairs appear side by side in the alphabet?

>
> >
> Firstly, my desire to make a keyboard map is to have something sooner
> rather than later: I want to have something to use to write
> messages/letters in (junior) QuickScript. For most of my
> letter-writing, and ALL of my programming, I will still use the
> standard qwerty/roman layout. Programmers in Russia, India, Japan,
> etc. do this all the time: the Latin alphabet (and English words
> written in it) is the current standard for programming.

Junior QS is fine, but I enjoy being able to also produce computer
script in senior QS. Jerome has a problem with the cursor position,
however. As a programmer, any idea if this could be corrected without
tons of trouble?
It would seem to me based on your comments and the little I know of
unicode, that it would make more sense to have a separate coding for QS.

>
>
> I would also like the see a 'senior' version of QuickScript available,
> and for this all the possible ligatures need to be identified. They do
> not need to be included in the Unicode proposal, though identifying
> them at the time of proposal is suggested. (At least, that is my
> understanding.) The additional combining glyphs can be added as
> ligatures when the font is created.
>
> > Finally, an even crazier idea. How about a locale en_jQS? Take a linux
> > (or some other malleable OS) installation, translate all the message
> > catalogs into Junior QS (with simple software and a dictionay this can
> > be done rather easily I think -- except for the lack of a monospace
> > font for JQS). Voila! The entire system in QS (almost)!

I blush to admit that at first sight I thought en_jQS was some esoteric
programming term I had never run across previously.

> > This is only my second post (as far as I know) to this group so sorry
> > if these ideas are old and have been rehashed as nauseum in the past.
> > Please tell me if that is the case.
>
> Not at all! Even though I don't actually agree with everything you
> suggest, I am very happy to have this level of conversation going on
> about the Read Alphabet.

I am also happy to have this in depth conversation taking place. Maybe
we will lure other lurkers out of the underbrush.

>
> As you can see from the rest of my message, I keep going back and
> forth between using
> QuickScript and the Read Alphabet. jQS and sQS are reasonable
> acronyms, I think... despite there being no 'q' letter in QS!

The name "Read alphabet" was chosen to honor Kingsley Read since I felt
he deserved it. The name strikes me as more dignified than quikscript
although I have always thought of it as quikscript since that is the
name Read gave it.

Any thoughts on whether we should promote the use of the name "Read
alphabet." "RA" as an acronym would work fine -- it's not far removed
from "RP."

Paige G.



>
>
> oliver
>
>
